title: Formatting a Password file in ,CSV format
content:
Hello and I hope you're having a good one!

I lost the password to my Bitwarden account but luckily I set that account to never log out since I'm the only person with access to my desktop running Windows 11. So I can access it regardless.

I then created a new Bitwarden account then painstakingly one by one put the 140 login sites into a .txt file. Web address, Username, Password

Skipped two spaces and did that again. 140 times. Ughhh... I converted that Plain Text file into an Excel csv file.

When I try to import that to Firefox, which I can then import to my BW Vault, Firefox gives me an error, (see attached screenshot) which I think means my .csv file is incorrectly formatted. How can I fix that?

Any guidance will be greatly appreciated. And yes, I have taken proper precautions of saving my new BW Master Password securely in two places.
creator: michael.burns58

title: Runs out of memory
content: I subscribe to the digital edition of the Daily Mail. This creates on my desktop an identical version of the paper copy. It progressively uses more and more memory as I turn and enlarge/reduce page sizes to read articles etc. I have 32 gb of memory and it eventually runs out of memory with unpredictable results. I have to abandon Firefox and read the paper on Chrome. This behaves correctly and doesn't consume increasing amounts of memory.
creator: pahh1

title: How to delete all bookmarks in Firefox Desktop
content:
Note: I always export all bookmarks to backup file and copy that to several safe locations for needed synchronization across different browsers and also restoring them if needed. Problem: I have repeatedly selected all items in Firefox bookmarks sub-folders and then followed by importing html bookmarks thinking that I was updating my bookmarks, so all my browsers had same. Instead, what I find is duplicated sets of bookmarks building up about 10-fold so that now any search for a site yields far too many duplicate listings and it is a mess. How do I prevent this from happening and how do I actually and truly delete all boomkarks in Firefox?

Aside topic: For all the folks who have accidentally lost bookmarks, my experience with losses has lead to always having backup files of bookmarks and backup listings in word or Excel of all my settings and extensions, etc. Automation has advantages, but it introduces new headaches. I can never allow myself to believe that everything will one day be just rosy. Also, multiple different browsers can be very helpful.
creator: Firefox_Ji1H4m
